attributes.title: Convolutional Neural ODE MNIST Classifier on GPU

children: Convolutional Neural ODE MNIST Classifier on GPU
Training a Convolutional Neural Net Classifier for
using a neural ordinary differential equation
# Use MLDataUtils LabelEnc for natural onehot conversion
# Use Flux's DataLoader to automatically minibatch and shuffle the data
# To understand the intermediate NN-ODE layer, we can examine it's dimensionality
# We can see that we can compute the forward pass through the NN topology
# Monitor that the weights do infact update
Ensures that only optimized kernels are called when using the GPU. Additionally, the
function is shown as a way to translate models and data over to the GPU. Note that this function is CPU-safe, so if the GPU is disabled or unavailable, this code will fallback to the CPU.
where the raw MNIST data is split into features
will then transform the current labels (

meaning that every minibatch will contain 128 images with a single color channel of 28x28 pixels. The entire dataset of 60,000 images is split into the train and test dataset, ensuring a balanced ratio of labels. These splits are then passed to Flux's DataLoader. This automatically minibatches both the images and labels. Additionally, it allows us to shuffle the train dataset in each epoch while keeping the order of the test data the same.
# Use MLDataUtils LabelEnc for natural onehot conversion
# Use Flux's DataLoader to automatically minibatch and shuffle the data
The Neural Network requires passing inputs sequentially through multiple layers. We use
which allows inputs to functions to come from previous layer and sends the outputs to the next. Four different sets of layers are used here:
: This layer downsamples our images into
dimensional features. It takes a 28 x 28 image, and passes it through a convolutional neural network layer with
: A 2 layer Convolutional Neural Network Chain with
activation which is used to model our differential equation
: The final fully connected layer which maps our learned features to the probability of the feature vector of belonging to a particular class
: A utility function which transfers our model to GPU, if one is available
, we can use the following function as a cheap conversion of
from the ODE solver into a Matrix that can be used in the following layer:
For CPU: If this function does not automatically fallback to CPU when no GPU is present, we can change
Next we connect all layers together in a single chain:
There are a few things we can do to examine the inner workings of our neural network:
# To understand the intermediate NN-ODE layer, we can examine it's dimensionality
# We can see that we can compute the forward pass through the NN topology
This can also be built without the NN-ODE by replacing
# We can also build the model topology without a NN-ODE
To convert the classification back into readable numbers, we use
which returns the prediction by taking the arg max of the output for each column of the minibatch:
We then evaluate the accuracy on
at a time through the entire network:
Once we have our model, we can train our neural network by backpropagation using
is the loss function computed here which applies a
operation on the final output of our model.
takes in the prediction from our model
and compares it to actual output
is specified here as our optimizer with a
This callback function is used to print both the training and testing accuracy after 10 training iterations:
To train our model, we select the appropriate trainable parameters of our network with
. In our case, backpropagation is required for
. Notice that the parameters for Neural ODE is given by
